threat_description: Quantum-safe readiness gap: Organizations score average 25/100 on IBM Quantum-Safe Readiness Index. 70% lack complete cryptographic inventory, creating massive vulnerability window. Estimated 5-6 year gap between CRQC arrival and organizational readiness completion.
crypto_at_risk: All asymmetric cryptography, PKI infrastructure, key management systems
pqc_replacement: Comprehensive CBOM, automated discovery tools, ML-KEM/ML-DSA migration

threat_description: Vendor dependency crisis: 62% of organizations incorrectly assume vendors will manage quantum-safe transition automatically. Lack of contractual PQC requirements and service-level agreements for crypto-agility.
crypto_at_risk: Third-party API keys, vendor-managed HSMs, cloud KMS
pqc_replacement: Vendor PQC roadmap requirements, contractual crypto-agility clauses

threat_description: Authentication infrastructure quantum vulnerability: Modern authentication systems (digital certificates, SSO platforms, MFA devices, FIDO2) rely on quantum-vulnerable PKI. Migration to PQC-compatible certificate chains lagging across enterprises.
crypto_at_risk: X.509 certificates, SAML assertions, OAuth/OIDC tokens, FIDO2 attestation
pqc_replacement: Hybrid certificate chains, ML-DSA certificates, PQC-enabled FIDO2

threat_description: Quantum-safe readiness score financial sector: Banking sector averages only 27/100 on quantum readiness despite being highest-risk industry. AI investments diverting resources from PQC migration.
crypto_at_risk: Payment systems, SWIFT infrastructure, trading platforms, custody solutions
pqc_replacement: Immediate PQC roadmap funding, ML-KEM for payment networks

threat_description: BIS Project Leap Phase 2 integration challenge: Central banks implementing quantum-safe wholesale CBDC settlement. Bank of Italy, France, Germany, Nexi testing hybrid PQC for $5+ trillion daily cross-border transactions.
crypto_at_risk: Wholesale CBDC infrastructure, cross-border settlement, central bank digital currencies

threat_description: CNSA 2.0 compliance deadline pressure: NSS acquisitions must be CNSA 2.0 compliant by January 2027. Current vendor ecosystem lacks certified implementations creating procurement crisis.
crypto_at_risk: Federal PKI, NSS communications, classified systems, defense supply chain
pqc_replacement: FIPS 140-3 validated PQC modules, CMVP certification acceleration

threat_description: Federal PQC product category list gap: CISA January 2026 product category list identifies where PQC is widely available followed by approved products list. Vendors without PQC FIPS validation risk federal contract exclusion.
crypto_at_risk: COTS products, federal IT infrastructure, defense systems
pqc_replacement: NIST FIPS 203/204/205 compliance, ACVP testing, vendor roadmaps

threat_description: Healthcare cloud encryption crisis: Only 4% of healthcare operators encrypted 80%+ of sensitive cloud data. Thales 2025 report shows 58% evaluating PQC but low actual deployment.
crypto_at_risk: EHR databases, medical imaging, patient portals, health information exchanges
pqc_replacement: Immediate cloud encryption deployment, ML-KEM-768, AES-256-GCM

threat_description: Medical device lifecycle quantum exposure: FDA guidance requires PQC alignment by 2030. Devices with 10-20 year lifecycles being deployed now will be vulnerable. 465000+ pacemakers affected by crypto failures.
crypto_at_risk: Implantable device crypto, medical IoT, remote patient monitoring, BLE pairing
pqc_replacement: Crypto-agile device design, hybrid firmware updates, ML-DSA signing

threat_description: 5G Americas PQC integration timeline: 5G network slicing authentication and RAN encryption vulnerable. GSMA Post-Quantum Telco Network Taskforce established 2025 for coordinated transition.
crypto_at_risk: 5G slice isolation, RAN encryption, N2/N3 interfaces, IPsec/IKEv2
pqc_replacement: 3GPP Release 19 PQC, ML-KEM for 5G SA, hybrid authentication

threat_description: Smart meter PQC replacement crisis: 1 billion+ smart meters globally require PQC upgrade by 2035. UK 38 million meters lack OTA capability requiring physical hardware replacement.
crypto_at_risk: AMI mesh networking, meter PKI, demand response, distribution automation
pqc_replacement: Quantum-safe AMI protocols, hardware replacement programs, ML-KEM metering

threat_description: Power grid SCADA quantum vulnerability: University of Toronto $1.45M research identifies real-time attack scenarios for grid controllers, smart meters, energy routers once CRQCs available.
crypto_at_risk: SCADA/ICS protocols, PMU authentication, grid synchronization, EMS communications
pqc_replacement: IEC 62351 quantum update, hybrid QKD/PQC, constrained device PQC

threat_description: V2X PKI quantum transition: Vehicle-to-Everything communications using ECDSA P-256. 12+ year vehicle lifecycle means 2026 production vehicles vulnerable through 2038+.
crypto_at_risk: V2X certificates, OTA updates, digital keys, in-vehicle authentication
pqc_replacement: SAE J2945 PQC update, ML-DSA V2X, Falcon for constrained ECUs

threat_description: BIS Project Leap / SWIFT quantum migration challenge: Central banks and SWIFT implementing quantum-safe protocols for $5+ trillion daily transactions. Phase 2 launched July 2025 with Bank of Italy, France, Germany, and Nexi.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048, ECDSA, TLS legacy

threat_description: Harvest-now-decrypt-later on long-lived financial records: Attackers exfiltrating encrypted transactional data, regulatory archives, and market infrastructure logs for future quantum decryption.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECDSA, TLS 1.2

threat_description: HNDL on classified data: TOP SECRET information requiring 25-75+ year protection is actively harvested for future quantum decryption. Current encryption provides no protection against this threat.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048/4096, ECDH P-384, ECDSA

threat_description: HSM backup key extraction for national security systems: Federal PKI root keys, military encryption keys, and NSS credentials recoverable from archived backups.
crypto_at_risk: RSA key wrapping, ECDH

threat_description: Nuclear command and control manipulation: NC3 systems with 50+ year lifecycles face highest-consequence quantum threat scenarios.
crypto_at_risk: All public-key cryptography

threat_description: Satellite communication interception: Military and intelligence satellite uplink/downlink communications vulnerable to quantum decryption. Space-based QKD deployment ongoing but limited.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECDSA satellite crypto

threat_description: HNDL on patient records: Healthcare data has lifetime sensitivity; genomic data and mental health records remain sensitive indefinitely. HIPAA mandates 6+ year retention but records persist 25+ years.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECDH, ECDSA, TLS

threat_description: Connected medical device cryptographic failure: FDA recalls affected 465,000+ pacemakers; devices with 10-20 year lifecycles will operate when CRQCs arrive.
crypto_at_risk: BLE cryptography, TLS, embedded ECC

threat_description: FDA PQC compliance timeline: Medical devices must align with NIST standards by 2030 per FDA guidance. Devices with 10-20 year lifecycles being deployed now will be vulnerable.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECDSA in medical devices

threat_description: Healthcare data breach quantum threat: 677 major breaches in 2024 compromising 182M+ records. Only 4% of sensitive healthcare cloud data properly encrypted. Thales 2025 report shows 58% evaluating PQC.
crypto_at_risk: Cloud encryption, database TLS

threat_description: HNDL on subscriber data: Mobile network operators retain call detail records, location data, and encrypted communications for 2-10 years. 5G user data encrypted with vulnerable algorithms.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECDSA, AES-128 (some legacy)

threat_description: RAN and core network encryption failure: Radio Access Network and Evolved Packet Core encryption vulnerable. GSMA Post-Quantum Telco Network Taskforce established 2025.
crypto_at_risk: IPsec, IKEv2, N2/N3 interface crypto

threat_description: SCADA system authentication bypass: Industrial control systems in power generation, transmission, and distribution using RSA-2048 or weaker.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-1024/2048, legacy protocols

threat_description: Nuclear facility cybersecurity failure: Digital instrumentation and control systems at nuclear power plants with 60+ year operating licenses.
crypto_at_risk: Safety system cryptography

threat_description: Aircraft avionics cryptographic failure: ARINC 664 (AFDX) network security and aircraft systems with 30-40 year service lives vulnerable.
crypto_at_risk: Avionics PKI, ARINC 664

threat_description: Space segment communication interception: Commercial and military satellites, ground stations, and inter-satellite links vulnerable to quantum attacks.
crypto_at_risk: Satellite TLS, uplink/downlink crypto

threat_description: IoT device authentication and provisioning: Billions of constrained devices with limited crypto-agility. Average risk score increased 33% in 2025 per Forescout.
crypto_at_risk: ECDSA P-256, RSA-2048

threat_description: Industrial IoT and IIoT SCADA: Manufacturing sensors, predictive maintenance, and factory automation vulnerable. IIoT breach cost $4.97M in 2024.
crypto_at_risk: OPC UA security, IIoT protocols

threat_description: Smart meter quantum vulnerability: 1 billion+ smart meters globally require PQC upgrade by 2035. Many lack OTA update capability requiring physical replacement.
crypto_at_risk: Smart meter PKI, mesh crypto

threat_description: Cloud backup and disaster recovery: Air-gapped backups and long-term archival storage vulnerable to harvest-now-decrypt-later.
crypto_at_risk: Backup encryption, archival

threat_description: Open source cryptographic libraries: OpenSSL 3.5 released April 2025 with PQC. Libsodium and others lagging. Widespread dependency risk.
crypto_at_risk: Legacy crypto in libraries

threat_description: Certificate Authorities and PKI: Public CA infrastructure must migrate to PQC. Browser and OS trust store updates required.
crypto_at_risk: CA root keys, intermediate certs

threat_description: Content encryption and studio IP: Master keys protecting unreleased films, streaming libraries, and production assets with decades of value.
crypto_at_risk: AACS, PlayReady, FairPlay

threat_description: DRM HSM backup key extraction: Master keys protecting entire studio content libraries worth billions recoverable from backups.
crypto_at_risk: RSA key hierarchy

threat_description: Long-term document signature validity collapse: Legal documents require 50-100+ year validity. Property deeds and constitutional documents lose legal standing when signatures forgeable.
Bitcoin ECDSA transaction hijacking: ~$718B in quantum-vulnerable addresses with exposed public keys. Early P2PK addresses including Satoshi's ~1.1M BTC permanently vulnerable.
crypto_at_risk: secp256k1 ECDSA

threat_description: Harvest Now Decrypt Later (HNDL) attacks targeting long-lived financial data including transaction records and settlement logs. Federal Reserve research confirms cryptocurrency networks face permanent data privacy risks from HNDL even with future PQC deployment.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048, ECDSA, ECDH, ECC-256/384
main_source: Federal Reserve Board FEDS Paper September 2025

threat_description: Healthcare HNDL exposure critical: Only 4% of healthcare operators have encrypted 80%+ of sensitive cloud data. Health records retain sensitivity indefinitely making them prime HNDL targets. 677 major breaches in 2024 exposed 182M+ individuals globally.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECC, TLS protocols protecting EHRs, HIPAA-compliant encryption
main_source: Thales 2025 Data Threat Report Healthcare Edition

threat_description: G7 Cyber Expert Group coordinated PQC migration statement January 2026: G7 CEG chaired by U.S. Treasury and Bank of England sets 2035 target for financial sector quantum-safe migration. Establishes coordinated roadmap across G7 nations for critical financial infrastructure.
crypto_at_risk: Cross-border payment systems, SWIFT, central bank settlement, securities infrastructure
pqc_replacement: Coordinated G7 PQC standards, ML-KEM/ML-DSA for payment networks, hybrid TLS 1.3

threat_description: EMV offline authentication RSA vulnerability: EMV chip card offline authentication (CDA/DDA) relies exclusively on RSA as the only approved asymmetric algorithm per EMVCo Book 2. Over 10 billion EMV cards in circulation globally. Quantum forgery of ICC certificates enables counterfeit card production that passes offline authentication. Migration requires coordinating card profiles, terminal software, CA public keys, and issuer certificate hierarchies across the entire ecosystem.
pqc_replacement: ML-DSA hybrid certificates, Falcon for constrained ICC chips
main_source: EMVCo Book 2 - Security and Key Management

threat_description: Card network CA key hierarchy quantum compromise: Visa and Mastercard maintain RSA CA public keys anchoring trust chains for all chip card authentication globally. Quantum compromise of a network-level CA key enables forgery of issuer and ICC certificates across billions of cards. G7 CEG 2035 financial sector migration target implicitly covers card networks as critical financial infrastructure.
crypto_at_risk: Visa/Mastercard CA RSA public keys, Issuer Public Key Certificates, ICC Public Key Certificates
pqc_replacement: PQC CA key hierarchy, ML-DSA issuer and ICC certificates
main_source: EMVCo Book 2 / G7 Cyber Expert Group

threat_description: Payment HSM key hierarchy quantum exposure: Payment HSMs protecting master keys, zone master keys, and key encryption keys use RSA key transport. HSM backup archives containing RSA-wrapped key material susceptible to HNDL. Leading vendors (Thales payShield, Utimaco, Futurex) have begun PQC roadmaps but FIPS 140-3 validated PQC HSM firmware not yet widely available.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048 key transport, RSA key wrapping in HSM backups
pqc_replacement: ML-KEM-768/1024 for key transport, AES-256 key wrapping, PQC HSM firmware

threat_description: PIN block DUKPT and RSA key injection vulnerability: Legacy deployments use Triple-DES DUKPT with RSA key transport for initial key injection into PIN entry devices. RSA-wrapped initial key injection is the primary quantum attack vector. AES-256 DUKPT (ANS X9.24-3:2017) mitigates symmetric key concern but does not address RSA key injection. Millions of terminals with 5-7 year replacement cycles still deployed.
crypto_at_risk: 3DES DUKPT base derivation keys, RSA-2048 key injection transport
pqc_replacement: AES-256 DUKPT, ML-KEM key injection, TR-34 with PQC
main_source: PCI PIN Security Requirements v3.1 / ANS X9.24

threat_description: Payment network TLS/gateway quantum vulnerability: PCI DSS v4.0.1 Requirement 4 mandates strong cryptography for cardholder data in transit. Current TLS 1.2/1.3 with RSA/ECDHE key exchange between terminals, gateways, acquirers, and card networks is quantum-vulnerable. HNDL attacks on payment traffic could expose credential and key material. PCI DSS 12.3.3 cryptographic inventory requirement provides foundation for PQC migration.
crypto_at_risk: TLS 1.2/1.3 RSA/ECDHE key exchange, payment gateway certificates
pqc_replacement: Hybrid TLS 1.3 with ML-KEM, ML-DSA certificates

threat_description: HNDL attacks on long-lived insurance records: Life insurance policies span 30-80+ years, annuity contracts 20-40 years, workers' compensation claims active for decades. Records contain sensitive PII (health data, financial data, SSNs) encrypted with quantum-vulnerable algorithms. Insurers legally required to retain records for extended periods. HNDL threat well-established by NIST and NSA as present-day risk for any organization holding long-lived sensitive data.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048/4096, ECDSA, ECDH, TLS 1.2 protecting policy databases

threat_description: Cyber insurance underwriting model disruption from quantum risk: Current actuarial models for cyber risk pricing do not account for systemic risk of CRQCs. A CRQC event triggers correlated claims across entire cyber insurance book simultaneously. Geneva Association and Lloyd's identify systemic cyber risk as major concern; quantum computing represents most extreme manifestation. Current exclusions and sub-limits may be insufficient for quantum-triggered events.
crypto_at_risk: All RSA/ECC-dependent systems across insured portfolio, cyber insurance risk models
pqc_replacement: PQC-readiness in underwriting criteria, quantum risk accumulation modeling

threat_description: Insurance regulatory compliance gap: NAIC Insurance Data Security Model Law (MDL-668) and state implementations (NY DFS 23 NYCRR 500) require encryption of nonpublic information using standards deemed effective. When CRQCs arrive, RSA-2048 and ECC will no longer qualify as effective encryption, potentially placing insurers in regulatory non-compliance. NY DFS requires risk assessments covering emerging threats including quantum computing.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048, ECC P-256, TLS 1.2 protecting policyholder data

threat_description: E-commerce payment data HNDL risk: E-commerce transactions transmit cardholder data encrypted with TLS using quantum-vulnerable RSA/ECDHE key exchange. PCI DSS 4.0 Requirement 4.2 mandates strong cryptography for data in transit but all approved asymmetric algorithms are quantum-vulnerable. Associated PII (names, addresses, purchase histories) retains long-term value for HNDL even as card numbers rotate.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048/4096 TLS key exchange, ECDHE P-256/P-384, RSA/ECDSA server certificates
pqc_replacement: Hybrid TLS 1.3 with ML-KEM-768, ML-DSA server certificates
main_source: PCI DSS v4.0 / Federal Reserve HNDL Research

threat_description: POS/mPOS terminal key injection quantum vulnerability: Millions of payment terminals use RSA-2048 for remote key injection (TR-34 protocol) and Triple-DES DUKPT for PIN block encryption. Terminal hardware replacement cycles of 5-7 years mean devices deployed today operational when CRQCs may arrive. Firmware signing relies on RSA/ECDSA code signing certificates vulnerable to quantum forgery.
crypto_at_risk: 3DES DUKPT, RSA-2048 TR-34 key injection, RSA/ECDSA firmware signing
pqc_replacement: AES-256 DUKPT, ML-KEM key injection, ML-DSA firmware signing
main_source: PCI PIN Security Requirements / ASC X9 TR-34

threat_description: Electronic Bill of Lading (eBL) signature forgery: eBL authenticated via RSA/ECDSA digital signatures per DCSA standards and UNCITRAL MLETR framework adopted by Singapore, UK, and others. CRQC could forge eBL signatures enabling fraudulent cargo claims, redirected shipments, and trade finance fraud. ICC estimates $18 trillion in annual trade could use eBL digitization, all dependent on signature integrity.
crypto_at_risk: RSA-2048/4096, ECDSA P-256 on eBL platforms, TLS for trade document exchanges
pqc_replacement: ML-DSA-65/87, SLH-DSA for archival, hybrid TLS 1.3

threat_description: Maritime GMDSS/VSAT communication encryption: Shore-to-ship and ship-to-ship encrypted channels use TLS/IPsec with RSA/ECDSA. IMO Maritime Cyber Risk Management guidelines (MSC-FAL.1/Circ.3) mandate cybersecurity but do not address quantum threats. HNDL on maritime communications exposes vessel movements, cargo manifests, and commercial shipping intelligence. Inmarsat and Iridium satellite links susceptible to state-level interception.
crypto_at_risk: TLS 1.2 certificates (RSA-2048), IPsec/IKEv2 for VSAT, satellite encryption

threat_description: Customs Single Window PKI compromise: WCO SAFE Framework and national Single Window systems (EU Customs, US ACE/ITDS) use PKI for customs declarations, pre-arrival processing, and AEO authentication. Quantum compromise enables forged customs declarations, sanctions evasion, and fraudulent duty-free claims. Over 120 countries implementing Single Window systems affected.
crypto_at_risk: X.509 certificates for customs, RSA/ECDSA on customs declarations, TLS for Single Window APIs
pqc_replacement: ML-DSA for customs signing, hybrid X.509, ML-KEM for API security

threat_description: Blockchain supply chain tracking quantum risk: Enterprise supply chain blockchains (Hyperledger Fabric) use ECDSA P-256 for transaction signing and endorsement policies. Quantum computers could forge transactions and compromise provenance guarantees. Federal Reserve HNDL paper confirms blockchain quantum risks.
crypto_at_risk: ECDSA secp256k1/P-256, SHA-256, TLS for node communications
pqc_replacement: ML-DSA for transaction signing, Falcon for constrained nodes, ML-KEM for peers
main_source: Federal Reserve HNDL Paper / Hyperledger Foundation
